questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent with abdominal pain and several episodes of vomiting. The vomit is dark red. The patient’s parent also found several opened pill bottles in the bathroom. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient lives in a newly built house with his parents and two older siblings. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a tired appearing child. Dried blood is present in the oropharynx. Peripheral pulses are weak, and capillary refill is 5 seconds. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally, and no abnormal heart sounds are heard. The abdomen is soft and mildly tender at the epigastrium. An abdominal radiograph shows radiopaque pills within the stomach. Laboratory results are shown below. Ingestion of which of the following agents is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with abdominal pain and dark red emesis. Imaging reveals the presence of radiopaque pills within the abdomen. He likely has acute iron toxicity due to ingestion of iron supplement pills.

Iron poisoning often occurs in children who accidentally ingest iron tablets after mistaking them for candy. Iron causes direct mucosal damage to the intestinal tract by free radical formation and lipid peroxidation. Local toxicity causes abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and gastrointestinal bleeding. Systemic toxicity can affect the cardiovascular system and liver, leading to distributive (vasodilation) and cardiogenic (iron-induced myocardial injury) shock and liver necrosis. Patients who survive acute poisoning may develop fibrosis or scarring of the gastrointestinal tissue, which can cause obstruction.

Laboratory testing will reveal an anion gap metabolic acidosis secondary to hypovolemia and hydrogen ion production during iron absorption. Imaging may reveal radiopaque pills within the gastrointestinal tract. Diagnosis is usually based on clinical presentation. A peak serum iron concentration confirms iron ingestion. Treatment involves aggressive fluid resuscitation, gastric lavage to remove any remaining iron from the stomach, and administration of deferoxamine. Deferoxamine is an iron-chelating agent that binds free iron and forms a complex that can be renally excreted.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

❌ Lead:
Incorrect: Acute lead toxicity can present with vomiting, abdominal pain, and altered mental status. Radiopaque objects may be seen on abdominal imaging. However, affected patients do not typically develop anion gap metabolic acidosis or hematemesis. Furthermore, this patient does not have potential sources of lead exposure (e.g., paint chips, contaminated water from lead pipes).  
✅ Iron:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin toxicity can present with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Patients may also develop tinnitus. However, aspirin pills are radiolucent and would not typically appear on abdominal imaging.  
❌ Acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen toxicity can present with vomiting and abdominal pain. Patients may also develop symptoms of liver injury such as jaundice, coagulopathy, and hepatomegaly. However, acetaminophen would not typically cause an anion gap metabolic acidosis.  
❌ Warfarin:
Incorrect: Warfarin poisoning typically presents with hemorrhagic bleeding (e.g., nosebleeds, melena, hematuria). The condition can develop due to over ingestion of warfarin pills or rodenticides (which  contain warfarin). However, warfarin toxicity would not typically cause an anion gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his son after being found unconscious in the home garage. The patient was in the garage for the past few hours repairing an antique automobile with the engine on. He regains consciousness shortly after arriving in the emergency room but appears lethargic and disoriented. Past medical history is noncontributory, and he does not take any medications. The patient has a 25-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 90/minute, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 98% of room air. Physical examination shows a confused adult male with flushed skin. Laboratory results and brain imaging are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
 

Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status, flushed skin, and a history of repairing a running vehicle inside his garage. Arterial blood gas reveals an anion gap metabolic acidosis, and brain MRI reveals signal hyperintensities in the basal ganglia. In combination, these findings are concerning for carbon monoxide poisoning.

Carbon monoxide (CO) is an odorless and tasteless gas. It avidly binds hemoglobin with an affinity approximately 250 times that of oxygen. Thus carbon monoxide displaces oxygen and impairs oxygen delivery to tissue, resulting in hypoxia. CO poisoning can be due to inhalation of smoke from fires or  burning of fuel sources such as wood and coal. It can also be caused by exposure to automobile exhaust or improperly vented natural gas appliances.

In mild to moderate cases of CO poisoning, patients can experience headaches, dizziness, nausea, and confusion. In more severe cases, patients may develop seizures, myocardial ischemia, and coma.

Vitals signs and pulse oximetry (which cannot distinguish between carboxyhemoglobin and oxyhemoglobin) are usually unremarkable. The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring elevated carboxyhemoglobin levels on blood tests. Imaging studies, especially brain MRI, may demonstrate signal hyperintensities in the bilateral basal ganglia.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

✅ Carbon monoxide poisoning:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Wilson disease:
Incorrect: Wilson disease can present with bilateral atrophy of the basal ganglia. Patients may have symptoms such as fatigue, abdominal pain, and uncontrolled or poorly coordinated movements. However, Wilson disease has a gradual, as opposed to acute, onset. Furthermore, it would not account for the patient’s anion gap metabolic acidosis.  
❌ Opioid overdose:
Incorrect: Opioid overdose may result in altered mental status, respiratory depression, and hypoxic brain injury. In contrast, although this patient was unconscious, his respiratory rate is actually elevated.  
❌ Acetaminophen intoxication:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen toxicity can present with nonspecific symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and malaise. Severe intoxication can cause liver damage and transaminitis. However, the condition would not result in MRI signal hyperintensities within the basal ganglia.  
❌ Heatstroke:
Incorrect: Heatstroke can occur in individuals exposed to extreme heat and humidity. Affected patients often have a body temperature of greater than 40°C (104°F) and can present with altered mental status, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension. In contrast, this patient has a temperature of 37.3°C (99.1°F), and heatstroke would not account for the patient’s imaging abnormalities.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to difficulty breathing. The patient is a farmer and developed symptoms while working in the fields. Past medical history is significant for major depressive disorder and two prior suicide attempts. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 53/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 90/65 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 87% on ambient air. Physical examination reveals a lethargic and diaphoretic adult female with bilateral pinpoint pupils and watering from the eyes. The patient’s body and clothes are soiled in vomit and feces. Lung auscultation reveals diffuse wheezing with rhonchi. Which of the following agents most likely precipitated this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with dyspnea, bradycardia, miosis, and excessive secretions (e.g., diaphoresis, lacrimation). These symptoms are highly suggestive of organophosphate poisoning.

Organophosphates can be found in insecticides, herbicides, and nerve agents. Agricultural workers are at increased risk for organophosphate poisoning. The substance binds to acetylcholinesterase (AChE), which is normally responsible for the hydrolysis of acetylcholine and renders the enzyme non-functional. With AChE blocked, acetylcholine subsequently accumulates and leads to hyperstimulation of nicotinic and muscarinic receptors. Nicotinic stimulation leads to neuromuscular blockade, and muscarinic activation results in increased visceral and glandular secretions. Organophosphates may also contribute to central respiratory depression, lethargy, and ultimately coma. A brief overview of the clinical features of organophosphate toxicity is found in the table below.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.


Option Analysis

❌ Atropine:
Incorrect: Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist. Atropine toxicity can present with mydriasis (dilated pupils), increased body temperature, constipation, and dry flushed skin. This patient’s presentation is inconsistent with the symptoms of atropine toxicity and instead more suggestive of organophosphate toxicity.  
✅ Organophosphate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Amitriptyline:
Incorrect: Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant with anticholinergic properties. Tricyclic antidepressant toxicity can present with mydriasis, increased body temperature, dry mouth, tachycardia, and flushed skin. This patient’s presentation is inconsistent with the symptoms of amitriptyline toxicity.  
❌ Caustic substances:
Incorrect: Ingestion of caustic substances (e.g., bleach, drain cleaners) can cause stridor, hoarseness, dysphagia, and oropharyngeal ulceration. In contrast to this patient’s presentation, it would not typically cause pinpoint pupils, bradycardia, or diaphoresis.  
❌ Amphetamine:
Incorrect: Amphetamine is a sympathomimetic agent. Although amphetamine overdose can present with tachypnea and increased sweating, the pupils are typically dilated, and blood pressure is elevated.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the emergency department after an episode of hematemesis, which occurred while he was at home eating dinner. Past medical history is noncontributory. After further evaluation, the patient undergoes an urgent upper gastrointestinal tract endoscopy. Benzocaine is used for topical anesthesia. Midazolam and fentanyl are administered for sedation. During the procedure, the patient’s oxygen saturation declines to 86% on ambient air, which fails to improve with the administration of supplemental oxygen. Physical examination shows bluish discoloration of lips and fingertips. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. The cardiac examination is unremarkable. The laboratory testing is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with new-onset hypoxia and cyanosis after receiving topical anesthesia and sedatives. These findings are suggestive of methemoglobinemia secondary to topical benzocaine use.

Methemoglobin is an altered state of hemoglobin that results from the oxidation of ferrous (Fe2+) to ferric (Fe3+) iron. As a result, the oxidized heme groups have a decreased ability to bind oxygen. To compensate, the remaining normal heme groups end up binding oxygen more tightly, which prevents them from releasing oxygen to the tissues. These changes ultimately cause tissue hypoxia. Medications associated with methemoglobinemia include topical/local anesthetics (benzocaine), dapsone, and nitrates.

Diagnosis is made by measuring elevated blood methemoglobin levels. Of note, pulse oximetry cannot be used to diagnose methemoglobinemia because methemoglobin absorbs light at the pulse oximetry’s two wavelengths, which leads to a reading of around 85% regardless of true oxygen saturation. Moreover, arterial blood gas studies analyze unbound oxygen and will show a falsely normal oxygen level.

Clinical symptoms of methemoglobinemia include cyanosis, dyspnea, confusion, and lightheadedness. In severe cases, patients may develop seizures, coma, and even death. Treatment involves removing the offending agent, providing supplemental oxygen, and administering methylene blue, which reduces methemoglobin back to hemoglobin.
 

 

Option Analysis

❌ Anaphylaxis to medication:
Incorrect: Anaphylaxis to a medication can lead to respiratory insufficiency and hypoxia. However, affected patients will likely have additional findings such as wheezing, stridor, hives, or swelling of the lips and tongue.  
❌ Fluid accumulation in the lungs:
Incorrect: Fluid accumulation within the lungs (e.g. pulmonary edema) is unlikely in this patient who has clear lung sounds bilaterally.  
❌ Air in the thoracic cavity:
Incorrect: A pneumothorax can lead to hypoxia and cyanosis. However, this patient has normal breath sounds bilaterally, whereas a pneumothorax would cause reduced breath sounds over the area of the pneumothorax.  
✅ Oxidation of heme iron:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibition of cytochrome oxidase:
Incorrect: Cyanide and carbon monoxide poisoning can lead to the inhibition of cytochrome oxidase. However, both of these conditions would typically present with flushed red skin, as opposed to cyanosis. Moreover, this patient’s symptoms developed after being exposed to benzocaine, which is more suggestive of methemoglobinemia.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man is brought to the office by his son due to increased forgetfulness and fatigue for the past three months. He has also been frequently stumbling and experienced several near-falls while climbing stairs. Review of systems is also notable for abdominal pain and numbness in the patient’s hands and feet. Past medical history is unremarkable, and he does not take any medications. He has been working as an automobile mechanic for the last 20 years. Vitals are within normal limits. The abdomen is soft, nontender, and without organomegaly on physical examination. Neurological examination reveals weakness and reduced pinprick sensation in the bilateral hands and feet. Upper and lower limb reflexes are 2/5. Laboratory testing is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has multiple symptoms suggestive of lead poisoning. These include:

Gastrointestinal symptoms: abdominal pain, constipation
Neurological symptoms: forgetfulness, peripheral neuropathy
Hematologic symptoms: microcytic anemia

Furthermore, chronic poisoning can also lead to nephropathy and hypertension.

Lead is absorbed through the lungs, skin, and GI tract. It then binds to erythrocytes where it interferes with enzymes involved in the heme pathway, leading to decreased hemoglobin synthesis. Common causes of lead toxicity in adults include occupational exposures, such as exposure to lead paint, batteries, and ammunition. Children can develop lead poisoning from ingesting lead-containing paint chips, which may be found in homes built before 1978.

Capillary blood tests are used for lead poisoning screening. However, the test can give false positives. Therefore, the diagnosis should be confirmed with venous lead levels. A complete blood count can be obtained to evaluate for microcytic anemia, and a peripheral blood smear may show basophilic stippling. Treatment involves removal of the lead source and chelation therapy with agents such as dimercaptosuccinic acid (also called succimer), dimercaprol, and calcium disodium edetate.  

Option Analysis

❌ Arsenic poisoning:
Incorrect: Arsenic toxicity often occurs due to occupational exposure or consumption of contaminated water or food. Arsenic binds to sulfhydryl groups and impairs cellular respiration. Symptoms include peripheral neuropathy, skin hyper/hypopigmentation, hyperkeratosis, pancytopenia, and transaminitis. This patient’s symptoms are instead more consistent with lead poisoning.  
❌ Vitamin B12 deficiency:
Incorrect: Vitamin B12 deficiency can result in subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord–manifesting with gait disturbance and impaired vibration sense. However, this condition is associated with a macrocytic, not microcytic, anemia.  
✅ Lead poisoning:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Iron overdose:
Incorrect: Iron toxicity most commonly occurs in children due to accidental ingestion of iron tablets. Local toxicity presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and bleeding. Patients may develop systemic toxicity, which can cause distributive and cardiogenic shock as well as liver necrosis. Laboratory testing will reveal an anion gap metabolic acidosis. However, this patient has peripheral neuropathy, forgetfulness, and microcytic anemia, which are more concerning for lead poisoning.  
❌ Parkinson disease:
Incorrect: Patients with Parkinson disease present with a shuffling gait, resting tremors, and muscle rigidity. Peripheral neuropathy and microcytic anemia are not usually associated with Parkinson disease.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner because of a mild headache, dizziness, fatigue, and nausea. The patient’s partner left their lakeside cabin earlier in the day to collect more firewood for their wood-burning stove. At the time, the patient was asymptomatic, and the symptoms had developed when the partner returned three hours later. Past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 126/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 129/66 mmHg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. He is confused and oriented only to person and place. The patient’s skin is dry and flushed. His gait is unsteady. Arterial blood gas analysis shows a carboxyhemoglobin level of 11%. Laboratory results are shown below. The patient’s symptoms improve after the administration of 100% supplemental oxygen. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Binding to the ferrous (Fe2+) iron in hemoglobin to form cyanohemoglobin
Inhibition of mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase
Free radical formation and lipid peroxidation

questions.solution:
This patient with a wood-burning stove presents with nausea, headaches, dizziness, and flushed skin. His symptoms improve with administration of 100% supplemental oxygen. Together, these findings are suggestive of carbon monoxide toxicity.

Carbon monoxide (CO) is a colorless and odorless gas that has a high affinity for cytochrome c oxidase in the electron transport chain. The binding of CO inhibits this enzyme, resulting in defective oxidative phosphorylation, ATP production, and aerobic metabolism. As a result, cells resort to anaerobic metabolism, resulting in lactic acidosis and eventual cell death. In addition, CO has a significantly higher affinity for hemoglobin than oxygen and causes a leftward shift of the oxygen dissociation curve. The end result is decreased oxygen binding capacity, increased hemoglobin affinity for oxygen, and subsequently decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.

Similarly, cyanide toxicity also inhibits cytochrome c oxidase and prevents oxidative phosphorylation. Furthermore, cyanide can bind to the ferrous (Fe2+) iron in hemoglobin to form cyanohemoglobin, which is unable to transport oxygen, which further exacerbates tissue hypoxia. However, unlike CO poisoning, cyanide poisoning does not affect the oxygen dissociation curve.  

Option Analysis

❌ Binding to the ferrous (Fe2+) iron in hemoglobin to form cyanohemoglobin:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes cyanide poisoning. Cyanide can bind to the ferrous (Fe2+) iron in hemoglobin to form cyanohemoglobin, which is unable to transport oxygen, which leads to tissue hypoxia. Similar to carbon monoxide poisoning, cyanide toxicity also inhibits cytochrome c oxidase and prevents oxidative phosphorylation, leading to further tissue hypoxia. However, this patient has a history of using a wood-burning stove in an enclosed space, which is more concerning for carbon monoxide poisoning.  
❌ Denaturation of globin chains:
Incorrect: This finding can occur in red blood cells deficient in glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD). In such cells, oxidative stressors can cause hemoglobin to denature. However, this patient’s symptoms are more consistent with carbon monoxide poisoning, which leads to inhibition of mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase.  
✅ Inhibition of mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibition of ATP synthase:
Incorrect: Oligomycin directly inhibits mitochondrial ATP synthase. In contrast, this patient has a history of using a wood-burning stove in an enclosed space, which is more concerning for carbon monoxide poisoning, which leads to inhibition of mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase.  
❌ Free radical formation and lipid peroxidation:
Incorrect: Iron poisoning can lead to free radical formation and lipid peroxidation; iron toxicity presents with abdominal pain, liver failure, and hemorrhagic gastritis. In contrast, this patient has a history of using a wood-burning stove in an enclosed space, which is more concerning for carbon monoxide poisoning, which leads to inhibition of mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of confusion and agitation. Past medical history is unknown. The patient is undomiciled and currently resides in a homeless shelter. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 100/55 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for mild epigastric tenderness. Fundoscopic examination shows optic hyperemia. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following agents was most likely ingested?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with confusion and epigastric pain. Laboratory testing reveals an increased osmolal gap (equation can be found below) and anion gap metabolic acidosis, while the physical examination is notable for optic disc hyperemia. These findings are suggestive of methanol poisoning.
 
 
Methanol toxicity usually develops when methanol is consumed as a substitute for ethanol. The condition initially manifests with altered mental status, abdominal pain, and vomiting. Over time, more serious complications such as vision loss and coma may develop since methanol is broken down by alcohol dehydrogenase to its toxic metabolites: formaldehyde and formic acid. Patients may have mydriasis and optic disc hyperemia or swelling secondary to optic nerve injury on physical examination. Other common findings include bradycardia, bradypnea, hypotension, and hyporeflexia.

Laboratory testing will reveal metabolic acidosis, elevated anion gap, and increased osmolal gap (since methanol is osmotically active).

Treatment options include fomepizole, a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase, or ethanol, which has a higher affinity for alcohol dehydrogenase than methanol. Both treatment options prevent the further breakdown of methanol into its toxic metabolites. Furthermore, sodium bicarbonate can be administered to alleviate the acidosis, and some patients may require hemodialysis.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.
 
 

Option Analysis

❌ Acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Patients with over-ingestion of acetaminophen present with relatively nonspecific symptoms of nausea, vomiting, malaise, and abdominal pain, which can progress to liver damage. Acetaminophen overdose does not cause anion gap metabolic acidosis, and ocular involvement is not usually seen.  
❌ Organophosphate:
Incorrect: Organophosphate poisoning presents with symptoms of cholinergic hyperactivity such as bradycardia, miosis, bronchorrhea, salivation, and lacrimation. This patient’s symptoms are inconsistent with those of organophosphate poisoning.  
❌ Lorazepam:
Incorrect: Patients with benzodiazepine overdose can present with nervous system depression and occasionally respiratory depression. However, benzodiazepine overdose would not typically cause an anion gap metabolic acidosis, increased osmolal gap, or ocular hyperemia.  
❌ Lead:
Incorrect: Patients with lead poisoning present with anemia, headaches, abdominal pain, and encephalopathy. Lead poisoning would not typically cause an anion gap metabolic acidosis, increased osmolal gap, and ocular hyperemia.  
✅ Methanol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of acute onset confusion, difficulty breathing, and diffuse muscle weakness. The patient is a farmer and was working in the field when symptoms developed. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 35/min, respirations are 42/min, and blood pressure is 90/65 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 88% on ambient air. Physical examination reveals a lethargic adult male. The patient’s body and clothes are soiled with vomit and feces. The patient’s pupils are constricted but symmetric and reactive to light. Lung auscultation reveals diffuse wheezing with rhonchi. Neurologic examination reveals hyporeflexia and 4/5 muscle strength. The patient’s wheezing improves after intravenous infusion of atropine. An additional agent is administered to help reverse diaphragmatic paralysis in this patient. Which of the following best describes this drug’s mechanism of action?

choices.text: Blockade of exocytosis of presynaptic acetylcholine vesicles
Blockade of choline uptake by presynaptic neuron

questions.solution:
This patient is a farmer and presents with confusion, muscle weakness, wheezing, and fecal incontinence. He most likely has organophosphate poisoning.

Organophosphates bind to and block acetylcholinesterase (AChE), which is normally responsible for the hydrolysis of acetylcholine and renders this enzyme non-functional. Without AChE, acetylcholine subsequently accumulates and leads to symptoms of nicotinic (neuromuscular blockade) and muscarinic (increased visceral and glandular secretions) receptor hyperstimulation.

Managing organophosphate poisoning involves initially stabilizing the airway (e.g. endotracheal intubation in patients with markedly depressed mental status), breathing, and circulation.

Decontamination (e.g., removal of clothes, irrigation of skin, administration of charcoal if organophosphate was ingested) should be performed to avoid continued exposure to the toxin.

Atropine, a competitive inhibitor of acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors, is administered to reduce bronchial secretions and stop wheezing. In patients with neuromuscular blockade, pralidoxime is then administered. Pralidoxime dephosphorylates acetylcholinesterase and reactivates the enzyme. It is important to administer pralidoxime after atropine, as the former can cause transient anticholinesterase inhibition and may briefly exacerbate symptoms.  

Option Analysis

✅ Dephosphorylation of acetylcholinesterase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibition of cholinesterase:
Incorrect: This patient is likely suffering from anticholinesterase poisoning and thus has impaired breakdown of acetylcholine. Administration of an agent like physostigmine, which inhibits cholinesterase, would cause further acetylcholine accumulation and exacerbate symptoms rather than treat them.  
❌ Blockade of exocytosis of presynaptic acetylcholine vesicles:
Incorrect: Botulinum toxin blocks the release of acetylcholine vesicles from the presynaptic neuron. However, it would not help reverse this patient’s symptoms which are due to the accumulation of unmetabolized acetylcholine already in the synaptic cleft.  
❌ Inhibition of choline acetyltransferase:
Incorrect: Bromoacetylcholine inhibits choline acetyltransferase and reduces the synthesis of acetylcholine. Bromoacetylcholine would not help reverse this patient’s symptoms which are due to the accumulation of unmetabolized acetylcholine already in the synaptic cleft.  
❌ Blockade of choline uptake by presynaptic neuron:
Incorrect: Hemicholinium blocks choline uptake by presynaptic neurons. Although this medication may help decrease acetylcholine synthesis, it is not typically used to treat the symptoms of organophosphate toxicity.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to a diffuse throbbing headache. Symptoms began several hours ago. Past medical history is significant for poorly-controlled hypertension, and he often forgets to take his medications. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years and drinks 1 or 2 glasses of wine daily. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 98/minute, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 210/155 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals no abnormalities. ECG and chest x-ray are unremarkable. The patient is immediately started on intravenous nitroprusside. Reevaluation after 5 hours reveals an improvement in blood pressure. However, the patient is now experiencing lightheadedness. He also appears confused and becomes unresponsive during further evaluation. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with hypertensive emergency and was started on nitroprusside therapy for rapid blood pressure control. Although his blood pressure improved, he subsequently developed lightheadedness and altered mental status, which are suggestive of cyanide toxicity.

Nitroprusside is a short-acting vasodilator that interacts with oxyhemoglobin to produce nitric oxide, methemoglobin, and cyanide. Patients treated with nitroprusside are at risk of developing cyanide toxicity, especially individuals with renal insufficiency or those receiving the drug at an increased infusion rate. Other causes of cyanide toxicity include inhaling smoke produced by the combustion of carbon and nitrogen-containing compounds (e.g., wool, silk) and ingestion of amygdalin, which can be found in apricot cores.

Cyanide is a potent inhibitor of cytochrome c oxidase, which is an enzyme in the electron transport chain. Therefore, cyanide is able to block ATP synthesis, leading to increased anaerobic metabolism and lactic acidosis.

Early signs of toxicity include headache, dizziness, vertigo, nausea, and vomiting. Neurologic, cardiovascular, and respiratory depression eventually occur leading to confusion, seizures, bradycardia, coma, cardiorespiratory arrest, and potentially death.

Option Analysis

❌ Ischemic brain injury:
Incorrect: In patients with chronic uncontrolled hypertension, cerebral vessels may not properly autoregulate. As a result, a significant drop in blood pressure may lower cerebral perfusion and lead to cerebral ischemia. However, cerebral ischemia would not account for this patient’s elevated lactate level and anion gap metabolic acidosis.  
✅ Cyanide toxicity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Aortic dissection:
Incorrect: Aortic dissection can occur in patients with uncontrolled hypertension. Affected patients present with severe tearing chest pain, and chest radiography may demonstrate widening of the mediastinum. In contrast, these findings are absent in this patient. Furthermore, this patient’s symptoms developed after administration of nitroprusside, which is more suggestive of iatrogenic cyanide toxicity.  
❌ Alcohol withdrawal  :
Incorrect: Alcohol withdrawal can present with agitation, tachycardia, and mental status changes. It usually occurs in individuals with a history of heavy alcohol use. In contrast, this patient consumes only moderate amounts of alcohol. Furthermore, alcohol withdrawal would not account for this patient’s elevated lactate level and anion gap metabolic acidosis.  
❌ Hypertensive encephalopathy  :
Incorrect: Hypertensive encephalopathy presents with headache, nausea, vomiting, and non-localizing neurological symptoms in the setting of elevated blood pressure. However, this patient developed lightheadedness and altered mental status after his blood pressure had decreased, which makes hypertensive encephalopathy less likely.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious near the doorway of a smoke-filled house. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 120/minute, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Physical examination shows generalized flushing of the skin as well as black soot near the nares and mouth. There is no evidence of any burns or trauma. Capillary refill time is 5 seconds. Supplemental oxygen is administered. Laboratory results are shown below. Hydroxocobalamin is provided for medical management. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this medication?

choices.text: Increases the concentration of glutathione available for the conjugation of NAPQI
Increase the activity of NADH-methemoglobin reductase

questions.solution:
This patient has flushed skin and soot in the oropharynx (which is suggestive of smoke inhalation injury) after being in a house fire. Hydrogen cyanide and carbon monoxide are two major products of combustion. As a result, cyanide toxicity should be considered in patients with a history of smoke inhalation, carbonaceous material in the oropharynx, neurologic dysfunction, metabolic acidosis, and elevated serum lactate level.

For patients in whom clinical suspicion is high, airway protection should be achieved and high-flow supplemental oxygen should be given. Hydroxocobalamin and sodium thiosulfate can be used for treatment. Both medications avidly bind cyanide to form cyanocobalamin, which is excreted via urine.

Alternatively, a combination of sodium nitrite and sodium thiosulfate may be used for the induction of methemoglobinemia. When cyanide binds methemoglobin (formed by nitrites), a relatively less toxic cyanmethemoglobin is formed. It then combines with thiosulfate to form thiocyanate, which is renally excreted.

In case of dermal exposure to cyanide, clothing should be removed, and the exposed skin should be cleaned to prevent further absorption. Similarly, in cases wherein cyanide is ingested, decontamination with activated charcoal should be performed.

  

Option Analysis

❌ Opiate receptor antagonism:
Incorrect: Naloxone works via opiate receptor antagonism; it is used as an antidote for opioid overdose, which can result in altered mental status and respiratory depression. This patient is unconscious but her respiratory rate is elevated. Furthermore, this patient was in a house fire and has an anion gap metabolic acidosis, which is more suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Chelation of serum iron:
Incorrect: Deferoxamine is a chelating agent that can be used to treat iron poisoning, which can present acutely with abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and gastrointestinal bleeding. Although iron poisoning can cause an anion gap metabolic acidosis, this patient’s history of being in a house fire is more suggestive of cyanide or carbon monoxide toxicity.  
❌ Increases the concentration of glutathione available for the conjugation of NAPQI:
Incorrect: N-acetylcysteine is the antidote for acetaminophen intoxication; it works by increasing the concentration of glutathione available for the conjugation of NAPQI. Affected individuals can present with nonspecific symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and malaise. Severe intoxication can cause liver damage and transaminitis. However, acetaminophen toxicity would not account for the patient’s flushed skin. Moreover, this patient’s history of being in a house fire is more suggestive of cyanide or carbon monoxide toxicity.  
❌ Increase the activity of NADH-methemoglobin reductase  :
Incorrect: Methylene blue is an antidote for methemoglobinemia, which works by increasing the activity of NADH-methemoglobin reductase. Methemoglobinemia usually occurs secondary to exposure to oxidizing agents (e.g., dapsone, nitrates, topical and local anesthetics). Exposure to a house fire is more likely to cause cyanide or carbon monoxide poisoning.  
✅ Forms cyanocobalamin for urinary excretion  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by local paramedics. She was rescued from inside a burning building and had a generalized tonic-clonic seizure en route to the hospital. Past medical history is significant for major depressive disorder and multiple suicide attempts. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/minute, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg.  Oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals flushing of the skin. She is able to localize pain and respond to commands. There is no evidence of any burns or trauma. Laboratory results are shown below. 100% FIO2 is applied to the patient via non-rebreather. Which of the following best describes the underlying mechanism of this practice?

choices.text: Increase the activity of NADH-methemoglobin reductase
Competition with carbon monoxide to oxygenate tissues
Increases the concentration of glutathione available for the conjugation of NAPQI

questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status and seizures after being rescued from a building fire. Laboratory testing reveals an anion gap metabolic acidosis and elevated carboxyhemoglobin level. She is most likely suffering from carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning.

CO is an odorless and tasteless gas that avidly binds hemoglobin with an affinity approximately 250 times that of oxygen. Thus CO displaces oxygen and impairs oxygen delivery to tissue, resulting in hypoxia.

Treatment involves removing the exposure source, maintaining a patent airway, and providing ventilation assistance if necessary. Administration of 100% oxygen via a non-rebreather face mask (or endotracheal tube) provides oxygen to help displace CO from hemoglobin and decreases the half-life of CO (from 5 hours to 2 hours). Hyperbaric oxygen should be administered in cases of severe CO toxicity (CO level >25%, loss of consciousness, pH <7.1, and/or concern for end-organ ischemia) or in cases wherein the patient fails to improve after receiving face mask administered oxygen.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.   

Option Analysis

❌ Increase the activity of NADH-methemoglobin reductase:
Incorrect: Methylene blue is an antidote for methemoglobinemia, which usually occurs secondary to exposure to oxidizing agents (e.g., dapsone, nitrates, topical and local anesthetics). Affected patients present with cyanosis and bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes. In contrast, this patient has elevated carboxyhemoglobin levels, which is more suggestive of carbon monoxide poisoning.  
❌ Forms cyanocobalamin for urinary excretion:
Incorrect: Hydroxocobalamin is an antidote for cyanide poisoning. Although building fires may lead to cyanide poisoning, this patient’s elevated carboxyhemoglobin level is more suggestive of carbon monoxide poisoning.  
❌ Sodium channel blockade:
Incorrect: Phenytoin is an anti-seizure medication which works via sodium channel blockade. Patients with carbon monoxide poisoning may develop seizures, but the first step in management is to start oxygen therapy. Phenytoin therapy is generally not indicated in patients with carbon monoxide poisoning whose seizures are self-limited.  
✅ Competition with carbon monoxide to oxygenate tissues:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increases the concentration of glutathione available for the conjugation of NAPQI  :
Incorrect: N-acetylcysteine is the antidote for acetaminophen intoxication. Affected individuals can present with nonspecific symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and malaise. Severe intoxication can cause liver damage and transaminitis. However, acetaminophen toxicity would not account for the patient’s flushed skin or elevated carboxyhemoglobin. Moreover, this patient’s history of being in a building fire is more suggestive of cyanide or carbon monoxide toxicity.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after losing consciousness at work. The patient is somnolent but responds to vocal stimuli. He recalls that over the last 12 hours, he has been experiencing muscle spasms, blurred vision, dry mouth, and hallucinations. The symptoms started after  eating some wild berries that he had picked during a camping trip. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg. Physical examination reveals dry flushed skin and enlarged pupils. The bladder is palpable, and straight catheterization drains 450 mL of urine. Which of the following best describes the drug that can help reverse this patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status, blurred vision, dry mouth, flushed skin, and urinary retention. This constellation of symptoms suggests anticholinergic syndrome, likely due to intoxication from belladonna alkaloids in the wild berries. The central acetylcholinesterase inhibitor physostigmine can best treat the patient’s condition.  

Anticholinesterases, also termed indirect cholinomimetics, inhibit the enzyme acetylcholinesterase that typically degrades acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft. As a result, more acetylcholine molecules remain, causing increased and prolonged acetylcholine-mediated muscarinic and nicotinic effects. Examples of anticholinesterases include edrophonium, neostigmine, physostigmine, pyridostigmine, rivastigmine, galantamine, and donepezil.  



Option Analysis

❌ Centrally acting anticholinergic:
Incorrect: Benztropine is a centrally acting anticholinergic agent used to treat Parkinsonism. Given its anticholinergic properties, benztropine will most likely worsen this patient’s condition.  
❌ Centrally acting dopamine blocker:
Incorrect: Haloperidol is a centrally acting dopamine blocker used to treat psychosis. It has anticholinergic properties and will most likely worsen this patient’s condition.  
✅ Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ β1-adrenergic receptor blocker:
Incorrect: Metoprolol, a β1-adrenergic blocker, is used to treat angina, arrhythmias, and coronary artery disease. However, it would be ineffective in reversing this patient’s symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity.  
❌ μ-receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: Naloxone is a μ-receptor blocker used as an antidote for opioid overdose. However, naloxone is ineffective in reversing anticholinergic toxicity.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police officers after he and several friends were found in an abandoned house producing and using recreational drugs. The patient endorses blurry vision and a headache for the past two hours. Past medical history includes coronary artery disease, hypertension, and treatment-resistant depression. Current medications include aspirin, lisinopril, metoclopramide, metoprolol, and selegiline. Temperature is 99.1 ºF (37.3 ºC), heart rate is 108 bpm, respiratory rate is 18 bpm, blood pressure is 205/116 mmHg. The patient appears agitated and slightly confused. Cardiac exam reveals tachycardia and an S4 sound. The neurologic exam is unremarkable. Several of the patient’s friends demonstrated evidence of slow movement, rigidity, and a resting tremor on physical examination. Which of this patient’s medications protected him from experiencing the physical exam findings observed in his friends?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a hypertensive crisis, presumably a hypertensive emergency in light of his altered mental status. Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOI), such as selegiline, can cause serotonin syndrome when combined with other serotonergic medications and can also lead to hypertensive crises. Selegiline is an MAO-B subtype-specific MAOI that is often used to treat Parkinson disease given its role in dopamine metabolism.  

This patient’s friends have likely been exposed to the neurotoxin MPTP, which can be produced as an unintended product during the synthesis of recreational drugs (e.g. opioids). MPTP and its active metabolites can induce damage to the substantia nigra and result in the development of Parkinsonian features. Since MPTP cannot be broken down into active metabolites by MAO-B, selegiline offers a relative neuroprotective effect against MPTP neurotoxicity.

Option Analysis

❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: While aspirin can help prevent cerebrovascular accidents, which can cause permanent neurologic changes, it is unlikely that it is preventing Parkinsonism.
❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril can help reduce risk of myocardial infarction, ventricular remodeling and inappropriate renin-angiotensin-aldosterone activity, it does not prevent the development of Parkinsonism.
❌ Metoclopramide:
Incorrect: Metoclopramide is an anti-dopaminergic agent that can cause Parkinsonism features.
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Metoprolol does not prevent Parkinsonism
✅ Selegiline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 5-year old boy is brought to the emergency department after being found unresponsive by his grandmother. For the past week, the patient has had a fever and cough, and his grandmother has been providing him with over-the-counter anti-inflammatory medications for symptom control. Today, the boy vomited three times, and an hour later, he became unresponsive. On physical examination, the child withdraws to pain only. Abdominal examination demonstrates hepatomegaly. During the evaluation, the patient has a generalized tonic-clonic seizure, which terminates with administration of lorazepam. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates the following findings as documented below. Liver biopsy is most likely to demonstrate which of the following histopathologic findings?

Laboratory value  Result 
Sodium   142 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.2 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   1.5 mg/dL 
 Alanine transaminase  411 U/L 
 Aspartate transaminase  357 U/L 
 Bilirubin (total)  2.5 mg/dL 
 Serum ammonia  177 µ/dL

choices.text: Sinusoidal dilation with congestion and edema

questions.solution:
Reye syndrome is a rare but fatal disorder and occurs in children less than 16 who are treated with over the counter aspirin for viral infections like influenza A, influenza B, and varicella.

Although the pathophysiology of Reye syndrome is not fully understood, it is thought that aspirin induces hepatic mitochondrial injury in the setting of a viral infection, which results in the cells’ inability to break down fatty acids. Ultimately, this defect results in the characteristic finding of microvesicular steatosis without necrosis as seen in the image below.


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Mitochondrial injury also results in hepatocytes inability to clear ammonia, resulting in hyperammonemia, cerebral edema, and related sequelae (e.g., seizures, severe intractable vomiting, and altered mental status). A high-index of suspicion for this condition should be adopted for any child presenting with severe vomiting and altered mental status in the setting of a viral infection.

On laboratory evaluation, the most significant finding is elevated serum ammonia, in addition to elevated liver enzymes, abnormal coagulation parameters (e.g. elevated PT), and signs of hypovolemia (e.g. AKI). Cerebral edema is typically apparent in imaging studies.

Option Analysis

✅ Microvesicular fatty infiltration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hepatocytes with “ground-glass” cytoplasm:
Incorrect: In chronic hepatitis B infection, the hepatitis B surface Antigen (HBsAg) accumulates in hepatocytes, giving a “ground glass” appearance to the cytoplasm.
❌ Sinusoidal dilation with congestion and edema:
Incorrect: Marked sinusoidal dilation with congestion and edema is seen in patients with Budd-Chiari syndrome. This condition occurs secondary to hepatic venous flow obstruction and thrombus formation.
❌ Panlobular hepatic necrosis:
Incorrect: Panlobular hepatic necrosis is seen in patients with fulminant liver failure, which is most commonly due to acute viral hepatitis, though it can also be induced by toxins or drugs. However, in Reye syndrome, the liver biopsy demonstrates microvesicular steatosis without significant necrosis.
❌ Hepatocytes with eosinophilic intracytoplasmic globules:
Incorrect: Intracytoplasmic eosinophilic globules are seen in patients with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of severe abdominal pain,  nausea, and vomiting. The pain started three hours ago and has been increasing in severity. The patient admits to swallowing 30 pills of acetaminophen in an attempt to end his life. Temperature is 37.9 C° (100.2 F°), respirations are 15/minute, pulse is 92/minute, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg.  On physical examination, right upper quadrant tenderness is noted. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiologic process underlying this medication toxicity?
questions.solution:
This patient is having acetaminophen toxicity and is currently complaining of right upper quadrant abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting. Acetaminophen toxicity is the most common cause of acute hepatic failure in the United States from either intentional or unintentional overdose.

Acetaminophen is an antipyretic that works via inhibition of cyclooxygenase (COX) enzyme and subsequent inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis. The metabolism of acetaminophen occurs in the liver, and under normal circumstances, most of the acetaminophen is metabolized by glucuronidation and sulfation into non-toxic metabolites that are excreted in urine. A small amount is metabolized by cytochrome P450 into N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI), a highly toxic metabolite for the liver. Fortunately, NAPQI produced with appropriate doses of acetaminophen is quickly metabolized by glutathione into nontoxic metabolites.



 In case of acetaminophen overdose, the glucuronidation and sulfation pathways become overwhelmed --shunting remaining acetaminophen to be metabolized by CYP450 into NAPQI. The high amount of NAPQI depletes intracellular glutathione, resulting in accumulation of NAPQI within hepatocytes, causing cellular necrosis and death.

In addition to intentional overdose, some patients may develop toxicity with therapeutic doses. For example, people taking CYP450 enhancers (e.g. barbiturates) simultaneously with acetaminophen will increase NAPQI production and accumulation, leading to toxicity. Furthermore, patients with a baseline deficit in glutathione may develop hepatocyte injury with therapeutic doses of acetaminophen.

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

✅ Depletion of intracellular glutathione:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inhibition of cytochrome p450:
Incorrect: Cytochrome p450 (CYP450) is the enzyme responsible for converting acetaminophen into NAPQI-- the toxic metabolite known to induce hepatocyte necrosis. Inhibition of CYP450 will protect against acetaminophen toxicity.
❌ Inhibition of cyclooxygenase-2:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen exerts its analgesic and antipyretic effects by inhibiting COX-2, thereby reducing the production of prostaglandins. However, this mechanism does not describe acetaminophen-induced liver injury.
❌ Increased acetaminophen sulfation:
Incorrect: Metabolism of acetaminophen by sulfation yields non-toxic metabolites that are excreted in the urine. Overdose of acetaminophen leads to saturation of the sulfation pathway, with subsequent shunting towards metabolism by CYP450, which yields NAPQI, the toxic product responsible for hepatotoxicity in acetaminophen overdose.
❌ Increased acetaminophen glucuronidation:
Incorrect: Like sulfation, acetaminophen glucuronidation is another metabolism pathway of acetaminophen that yields non-toxic metabolites.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of a first-time seizure. The patient attended the party with three of his friends who report that he used a drug to help him “be more social.” His friends state the patient seemed to be drinking “copious amounts of water” at the party. His temperature is 38.5C (101.3F), pulse is 110/minute, respirations are 16/minute, and blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg. On physical examination the man is disoriented, the pupils are mydriatic, and he appears diaphoretic. Clonus is appreciated in the lower extremities bilaterally. Laboratory evaluation reveals hyponatremia. Which of the following agents is most likely responsible for this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with features consistent with serotonin syndrome--a hyperadrenergic state with associated clonus. Of the agents listed, 3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine or MDMA is highly associated with this clinical syndrome. This drug is often consumed at parties to produce euphoria and social connection.

MDMA, when consumed in excess, can be life-threatening. High doses of MDMA result in agitation and increased blood pressure, heart rate and temperature. In addition, this increased sympathetic activity can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, seizures, and death.

 


One of the major causes of death is hyponatremia, which results from increased water intake and inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). Ultimately, severe hyponatremia can lead to seizures (like this patient) and cerebral edema. Rhabdomyolysis and myoglobinuria are common as well, secondary to increased sympathetic
 activity.


People who use MDMA frequently often develop tolerance and dependence, and they may have withdrawal symptoms when abstaining from use. Withdrawal symptoms are not life-threatening, but they can be bothersome. Withdrawal symptoms include irritability, depression, insomnia, and anxiety. In addition, decreased appetite is usually seen, which may lead to weight loss. 

Option Analysis

✅ 3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Heroin:
Incorrect: Heroin intoxication is characterized by miosis, respiratory depression, and somnolence. This presentation is in contrast to this patient’s evidence of increased sympathetic activity (e.g., hypertension, tachycardia).
❌ Lysergic acid diethylamide:
Incorrect: This patient presents with evidence of severe hypertension, hyperthermia, and hyponatremia, which are not typically observed with LSD intoxication.
❌ Marijuana:
Incorrect: Marijuana is associated with injected conjunctiva and normal pupil size--not mydriasis.
❌ Cocaine:
Incorrect: Cocaine use is associated with first time seizures; however, this patient has evidence of serotonin syndrome (clonus), which is not typically observed with cocaine intoxication.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by EMS after he was found at a public park yelling at bystanders. Several unlabeled pill capsules are found in his belongings. Temperature is 100°F (37.7 °C), pulse is 117 bpm, respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute, and blood pressure is 177/90 mmHg. The patient appears agitated and diaphoretic. On physical examination, the patient has noted mydriasis bilaterally. There is absence of clonus in the lower extremities bilaterally. Oral mucosa appears moist. Intranasal examination reveals septal ulceration. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with psychomotor agitation, tachycardia, hypertension, septal ulceration, and aggressive behavior--suggestive of stimulant intoxication. Cocaine and associated amphetamines (MDMA, ecstasy, methamphetamine) are psychoactive stimulants with varying effects on the enhancement of dopaminergic, serotonergic, and noradrenergic activity in the central nervous system. Non-specific features of stimulant intoxication include anxiety, aggressive behaviour, psychomotor agitation, delirium, hypertension, tachycardia, pupillary dilation, mydriasis and diaphoresis. In high doses, hallucinations and paranoia may be present. In addition, serotonin syndrome may ensue if multiple, or high quantities of, serotonergic agents are ingested.

Abrupt cessation of stimulant use manifests with effects opposite to the intoxicating effects. These features include hypersomnia, increased appetite, pupillary constriction, psychomotor retardation and depression.

 


Option Analysis

✅ Amphetamine intoxication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cannabis intoxication :
Incorrect: Symptoms of cannabis intoxication include conjunctival injection, increased appetite, euphoria, paranoid delusions and a dry mouth. Pupillary dilation and diaphoresis are not typical of cannabis intoxication.
❌ Serotonin syndrome:
Incorrect: Serotonin syndrome is characterized by hyperactive reflexes, mydriasis, and hyperadrenergic drive. One of the key findings in cases of serotonin syndrome is the presence of clonus, which is absent in this patient.
❌ Opiate withdrawal syndrome:
Incorrect: Opiate withdrawal syndrome may manifest with many similar features of amphetamine intoxication syndrome including mydriasis, tachycardia, and hypertension. However, patients with opiate withdrawal syndrome will also typically exhibit piloerection, vomiting, and diarrhea.
❌ Benzodiazepine intoxication:
Incorrect: Psychomotor depression, respiratory depression, ataxia, and hypotension are features of benzodiazepine intoxication. A normal respiratory rate and hypertension as seen in this patient suggests an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician's clinic for evaluation of irritability, reduced concentration, and persistent headache. The headache is frontal, dull, and is not associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia or phonophobia. She has noticed that she has gained 5 lbs (2.27 kg) over the last two weeks due to an increased appetite. Prior to a week ago, the patient smoked 2-3 packs of cigarettes daily but stopped abruptly. She also stopped using several illicit substances and alcohol at this time when she found out her daughter was pregnant. The patient has a history of major depressive disorder and chronic back pain. Her current medications include escitalopram and oxycodone as needed. Temperature is 98 °F (36.6 °C), pulse is 110 bpm, and blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg. The patient appears irritable. Oral mucosa appears moist. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. The patient moves all four extremities to commands with normal deep tendon reflexes. Withdrawal from which of the following substances is responsible for the constellation of symptoms observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with irritability, weight gain, dysphoria, and increased appetite consistent with nicotine withdrawal. Nicotine is an alkaloid found in tobacco products that acts as a ganglionic and central nervous stimulant. Nicotine can impair endothelial function, promote coronary vasoconstriction and generate free radicals that impair tissue oxygenation. These actions are mediated by the increase in neurotransmitters including epinephrine, norepinephrine, serotonin, dopamine and acetylcholine.

Smoking can accelerate atherosclerosis and acts as an independent risk factor for coronary disease, myocardial infarction and sudden cardiac death. Symptoms of excess nicotine consumption include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and diaphoresis. Nicotine withdrawal commonly occurs  following abstinence, as its psychoactive features cause tolerance and dependency.

Clinical manifestations of nicotine withdrawal begin hours to days after cessation and subside in 3-4 weeks. Symptoms include weight gain, insomnia, irritability, increased appetite, poor concentration, depressed mood and restlessness. Nicotine replacement therapy and drugs like varenicline and bupropion are some of the treatment options for the management of nicotine withdrawal.

Option Analysis

✅ Nicotine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ethanol:
Incorrect: Alcohol withdrawal can present within 48 hours with tremors, anxiety, reduced sleep, agitation and seizures. However, this patient had her last drink one week ago.
❌ Morphine:
Incorrect: Manifestations of opioid withdrawal include piloerection, yawning, dilated pupils, lacrimation and hyperactive bowel sounds.
❌ Cocaine :
Incorrect: Withdrawal from psychostimulants like cocaine and amphetamines can cause severe psychomotor retardation (“crash”) along with hypersomnia, increased appetite and signs of severe depression. However, withdrawal symptoms from cocaine typically resolve on their own without treatment within one to two weeks.
❌ Methamphetamine:
Incorrect: Withdrawal from psychostimulants such as cocaine and amphetamines can cause severe psychomotor retardation (“crash”) along with hypersomnia, increased appetite and signs of severe depression.

questions.text: An 86-year-old man comes to the clinic for a routine physical evaluation. The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, major depressive disorder and chronic back pain. His current medications include metformin, amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, escitalopram, atorvastatin and oxycodone as needed. The patient uses illicit drugs including cocaine and has a 30-pack year smoking history. He consumes alcohol with his friends on the weekends. His last drink was two days ago. The patient’s father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 60, and his uncle died of an acute aortic dissection at the age of 70. Temperature is 98°F (36.6 °C), pulse is 90 bpm, blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg. Abdominal examination reveals a central pulsatile mass. HbA1c level on this visit is 9.0%. Which of the following risk factors places the patient in a high risk category necessitating ultrasonographic screening for this patient’s finding on the abdominal exam?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of tobacco use and a central, pulsatile abdominal mass likely has an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Patient’s over the age of 60 with any smoking history should be screened for the presence of this pathology. The primary risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysm include male sex, history of smoking, and age >60. A one time screening abdominal ultrasound is recommended by the US preventive task force for all men between the ages of 65-75 who have ever smoked in the past.

In addition, the most important causes of mortality associated with smoking use are lung cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Nicotine induces coronary vasoconstriction, stimulates thrombus formation, promotes hypercoagulability and endothelial dysfunction. Long-term cardiovascular complications with tobacco use include acute coronary syndrome, stroke and peripheral vascular disease.

Tobacco use acts as a significant causative factor for the development of multiple malignancies including lung cancer, squamous cell cancer of the esophagus, renal cell carcinoma, and head and neck cancer. Cigarette smoking is also an independent risk factor in the development of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Smoking cessation reduces the risk of progression of early COPD and has been shown to reduce severity of symptoms in the first 12 months after cessation.



Option Analysis

✅ Tobacco use:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyperlipidemia:
Incorrect: Hyperlipidemia is not as strong an association to the progression of abdominal aortic aneurysm as tobacco use. It is also not used as a screening criteria for abdominal aortic aneurysm.
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Abdominal aortic aneurysms are more common in patients with hypertension; however, tobacco use and age >60 are the critical risk factors when considering the screening for abdominal aortic aneurysms.
❌ Cocaine use:
Incorrect: Cocaine use is associated with an increased risk of acute aortic dissection. It is not associated with an increased risk of abdominal aortic aneurysm and is not considered a criteria for screening.
❌ Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus is a significant risk factor for atherosclerosis and acute coronary syndrome; however, tobacco use and age >60 are the critical risk factors when considering the screening for abdominal aortic aneurysms.

questions.text:
A 30 year-old woman comes to her primary care physician because of muscle cramps, nausea, and fatigue. The patient endorses a history of depression and seizure disorder, both of which are currently managed with medications. Family history is notable for Addison disease in her maternal uncle. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 14/min and blood pressure is 115/80 mmHg. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations are noncontributory. Additional laboratory results are as follows:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
Sodium   122 mEq/L 
 Potassium   3.7 mEq/L 
 Creatinine  0.9 mg/dL 
 Glucose  102 mg/dL 
 Serum osmolality   240 mOsm/kg 
 Urine osmolality  445 mOsm/kg 

Which of the following is the most likely explanation of the patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation (i.e. symptomatic hyponatremia, low serum osmolality and high urine osmolality) is consistent with the diagnosis of syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) secondary to medication(s). Antidepressants, such as selective-serotonin reuptake inhibitors, and antiepileptics, such as carbamazepine, can cause SIADH as a side-effect.

SIADH is a diagnosis of exclusion. In patients who are suspected of having this condition, the diagnostic workup involves obtaining a history, performing a physical examination, and obtaining laboratory testing. Symptoms can range from fatigue and nausea/vomiting in milder cases to coma and seizures in severe cases.  

Laboratory testing involves obtaining a serum sodium, serum osmolality, and urine osmolality. Results in patients with SIADH will show hyponatremia (secondary to dilution caused by fluid retention and reduced aldosterone secretion), reduced serum osmolality, and elevated urine osmolality. The workup also entails ruling out other conditions (e.g., hypothyroidism, adrenal insufficiency) by ordering TSH, T3 and T4 levels, and testing for serum cortisol concentration (e.g. morning serum cortisol).  

Option Analysis

❌ Diabetes insipidus:
Incorrect: Diabetes insipidus (DI) results from either decreased production of ADH from the posterior pituitary or resistance of the kidneys to ADH. The end result is significant water loss via urine that can cause dehydration. Individuals with DI present with elevated serum osmolality, which is inconsistent with this patient’s presentation.
❌ Adrenal insufficiency:
Incorrect: Adrenal insufficiency may cause hyponatremia. The patient’s family history of Addison disease (autoimmune destruction of the adrenal glands) increases her risk of developing the condition. Patients with adrenal insufficiency often become hypovolemic, resulting in an elevated serum osmolality and creatinine. While the patient has hyponatremia, her normal creatinine and reduced serum osmolality are suggestive of euvolemic hyponatremia.
❌ Primary polydipsia:
Incorrect: Primary polydipsia is a condition caused by abnormally increased thirst that leads to excessive intake of fluids. It is often associated with psychiatric conditions. Primary polydipsia presents with low serum and urine osmolality. In contrast, this patient’s urine osmolality is high, which is inconsistent with this diagnosis.
❌ Surreptitious diuretic use:
Incorrect: Inappropriate diuretic use can contribute to excess renal loss of water and salt, resulting in hyponatremia. However, given that diuretics cause volume depletion, evidence of hypovolemia (e.g., dry mucous membranes, elevated creatinine) would also be expected.     
✅ Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH):
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician’s clinic for evaluation of difficulty sleeping, reduced concentration, and headache. On average, the patient sleeps four hours every night. The patient’s headache is dull and frontal and not associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia or phonophobia. The patient has a history of bipolar disorder and chronic back pain. Her current medications include escitalopram, a combined estrogen-progesterone oral contraceptive agent, and oxycodone as needed for the back pain. She does not use tobacco. She consumes alcohol with her friends on the weekends. Her last drink was four days ago. Until three weeks ago, she regularly consumed 4-5 cups of coffee daily. Temperature is 98 °F (36.6°C), pulse is 88 bpm, blood pressure is 154/90 mmHg. The patient appears irritable. Oral mucosa appears moist. The patient moves all 4 extremities to commands with normal deep tendon reflexes. Urine toxicology screen is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a tension headache, reduced concentration, disturbed sleep and irritability following abstinence from caffeinated drinks. Together, her symptoms are most consistent with caffeine withdrawal.

Caffeine acts as an antagonist to adenosine receptors, which results in the enhancement of excitatory neurotransmitters acting on the central nervous system. Ultimately, this effect improves cognition and alertness when consumed in moderate doses. Excessive caffeine intake is associated with adverse effects including palpitations, headache, tremor, gastrointestinal upset and agitation. Rarely, cardiac arrhythmias are precipitated by caffeine intake.

Clinical manifestations of caffeine withdrawal include headache, flu-like illness, reduced concentration, disturbed sleep, irritability, nausea and muscle pain. The severity of symptoms often increases with abstinence from higher daily doses of caffeine. Symptoms often manifest within 24 hours of discontinuation and peak in 2-4 days. Intake of caffeine can relieve symptoms in as quickly as 30-60 minutes.

Option Analysis

✅ Caffeine withdrawal:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Major depressive disorder:
Incorrect: Although this patient exhibits symptoms of major depressive disorder (MDD), including reduced sleep and decreased concentration, her presentation does not satisfy the DSM criteria for MDD (4/9 clinical criteria for a duration of 2 weeks).
❌ Migraine:
Incorrect: Migraine typically presents as a severe, pulsatile, throbbing unilateral headache with or without aura. This patient has a dull, frontal headache.
❌ Sleep disorder:
Incorrect: Sleep disorders are characterised as persistent difficulty in initiating or maintaining sleep. They can only be considered after ruling out substance-induced and coexisting mental disorders as the underlying cause.
❌ Narcolepsy:
Incorrect: Narcolepsy is characterized by catatonia (sudden loss of muscle tone), excessive daytime sleepiness and hypnagogic or hypnopompic hallucinations.

questions.text: A 24-year old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner for evaluation of visual hallucinations. The patient states he can see “fire moving through the air” and that sounds “appear brighter.” The patient tells the physician he believes he is “having a bad trip because of a drug he took.” He has no history of psychiatric illnesses. Temperature is 37.1 °C (98.8 °F), respirations are 15/minute, pulse is 92/minute, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. The patient is oriented to place and time. Physical examination demonstrates mydriasis. Urine toxicology is negative. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with visual hallucinations and synesthesia (confounding of sensations, like hearing colors) after consuming an unknown substance. Given the negative urine toxicology screen, the most likely ingested agent listed is lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD). LSD is a hallucinogen that is frequently used to produce euphoria; however, overdose sometimes can lead to unpleasant effects and dysphoria.

LSD intoxication typically results in visual abnormalities, ranging from seeing abnormal colors to profound visual hallucinations in cases of over-ingestion. Some patients develop paradoxical dysphoria and paranoia. Orientation in LSD overdose is usually intact, and patients are aware that what they are experiencing is secondary to the drug's effects. On physical examination, patients with LSD intoxication may have a mild increase in blood pressure and heart rate, increased sweating, and mydriasis.

 


LSD does not cause dependence, and the patients do not experience withdrawal symptoms if the drug is abruptly stopped. However, LSD can lead to long term consequences such as flashbacks and, in severe cases, psychosis.

Treatment of LSD intoxication is usually supportive. Patients experiencing severe anxiety may be given a low-dose benzodiazepine, while patients who continue to have psychiatric manifestations may benefit from antipsychotics. 

Option Analysis

✅ Lysergic acid diethylamide:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Phencyclidine:
Incorrect: Phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication is characterized by aggressive, combative behavior, euphoria, and disorientation. On physical examination, nystagmus (not mydriasis) is typically seen. If consumed in excess, life-threatening hyperthermia, hypertension, and tachycardia may be observed.
❌ Cocaine:
Incorrect: Cocaine ingestion usually leads to agitation, euphoria, and paranoia. Increased sympathetic activity leads to severe hypertension, tachycardia, and mydriasis. Cocaine is one of the substances screened for with routine urine toxicology.
❌ Marijuana:
Incorrect: Marijuana intoxication at high doses can result in both hallucinations and dysphoria.  Conjunctival injection is expected to be seen with ocular examination. Marijuana is one of the substances screened for with routine urine toxicology.
❌ Heroin:
Incorrect: Heroin is one of the leading causes of drug related overdose. Intoxication is characterized by severe respiratory depression, miosis, hypotension, hypothermia, and decreased bowel sounds. Patients are typically disoriented or comatose in severe cases.

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravid woman at 34 weeks gestation comes to the clinic for a routine prenatal examination. She has noticed regular fetal movements and does not have complaints of vaginal bleeding, leaking or abdominal pain. She had an upper respiratory infection and hyperemesis in the first trimester that have since resolved. The patient uses illicit drugs including heroin, cocaine and marijuana. She does not use tobacco. Prior to conceiving, she would consume alcohol with her friends on the weekends. Temperature is 98°F (36.6°C), pulse is 110 bpm, blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg. Ultrasound reveals a biparietal diameter of 32 weeks and abdominal circumference of 28 weeks. Which of the following complications should be anticipated at the time of delivery?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of cocaine use presents with evidence of intrauterine fetal growth restriction (discordance between gestational age and fetal growth parameters). Fetal growth restriction is defined as an estimated fetal weight less than 10% for gestational age.

Fetal growth restriction is associated with uteroplacental insufficiency resulting from cocaine use, hypertension, or tobacco use. Cocaine is a potent psychostimulant that acts by blocking the reuptake of biogenic amines like norepinephrine, serotonin and dopamine and can promote vasoconstriction and thrombus formation. Vasoconstriction of the placental vessels is the predominant mechanism for cocaine-induced maternal and fetal complications. In addition, cocaine use during pregnancy is also associated with complications such as preterm delivery, abruptio placenta, and miscarriage.

Option Analysis

✅ Abruptio placenta:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Placenta previa:
Incorrect: Risk factors for placenta previa include previous cesarean deliveries, multiple gestation and previous placenta praevia. Patients with intrauterine growth restriction and cocaine use are not at a higher risk to develop placenta praevia.
❌ Fetal hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: Fetal hypoglycemia can result from maternal hyperglycemia, fetal pancreatic hyperplasia and fetal hyperinsulinemia.
❌ Uterine rupture:
Incorrect: Uterine rupture is an obstetric emergency that results in the rupture of all the uterine layers. Risk factors include previous cesarean delivery and recent blunt abdominal trauma.
❌ Fetal macrosomia:
Incorrect: Macrosomia (birth weight >4500g) is a consequence of gestational diabetes mellitus secondary to maternal hyperglycemia and fetal hyperinsulinemia. Cocaine use is typically associated with preterm delivery and low birth weight.

questions.text: A 24-year old man is brought to the emergency department by the police after being found wandering the streets screaming at bystanders. He resisted arrest and became physically aggressive. While a nurse attempts to place an IV, the patient screams and attempts to hit her. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.6°F), respirations are 20/minute, heart rate is 120/minute, and blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg. The patient is subsequently provided with intramuscular haloperidol. Urine toxicology confirms the use of a drug that exerts its effects by binding to and antagonizing N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors. Which of the following physical exam findings is highly associated with this drug?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with characteristic features of phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication--an analgesic and anesthetic drug that exerts its effects by antagonizing the N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors found in the hypothalamus, basal ganglia, and neocortex.

Mechanistically, PCP is classified as a dissociative anesthetic. It is most commonly inhaled, with a rapid onset of effects including dysphoria, agitation, and diminished pain perception. Aggressive combative behavior is usually seen in patients taking PCP and may lead to serious injuries to self or others. When consumed in excess, patients may suffer from seizures as well.

On physical examination, patients with PCP intoxication have evidence of hypertension, tachycardia, hyperventilation, and hyperthermia. Nystagmus is almost always observed on physical examination, often with associated miosis.



Option Analysis

✅ Nystagmus:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Conjunctival injection:
