A wide range of arrhythmias occurring at almost any intracardiac location can be seen with digoxin toxicity. It can include sinus bradycardia, paroxysmal atrial tachycardia with AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation. The arrhythmias are thought to result from increased calcium in the sarcoplasmic reticulum, which increases the cardiac contractility (secondary to the direct inhibition of Na+/K+ ATPase, which indirectly inhibits the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger).

Hypokalemia can precipitate toxicity by increasing digoxin binding at K+-binding sites on Na+/K+ ATPase. In contrast, hyperkalemia is a sign of digoxin toxicity as the inhibition of Na+/K+ ATPase increases extracellular potassium. Other factors that increase the risk of digoxin toxicity include:

  • Hypomagnesemia (which leads to hypokalemia)
  • Renal failure (decreased digoxin clearance)
  • Hypovolemia 
 


Option Analysis

❌ Atorvastatin:
Incorrect: Atorvastatin, a statin medication, is used to prevent cardiovascular disease in those at high risk and treat abnormal lipid levels. The most common side effects include myopathy and, more rarely, rhabdomyolysis.  
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Beta-blocker overdose can cause bradycardia and profound hypotension instead of tachycardia seen in this patient. Moreover, it typically causes bronchospasm and hypoglycemia, whereas anorexia and vomiting are more likely with digoxin toxicity.  
✅ Digoxin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide is more likely to cause hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia due to volume depletion.  
❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril overdose is associated with the development of hypokalemia, hypotension, and acute kidney injury. This patient's serum creatinine and blood pressure are within normal limits.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of a dry, nagging cough. He does not have chest pain or shortness of breath. The rest of the review of systems is within normal limits. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, congestive heart failure, and hypertension. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs. Temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 148/85 mmHg. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Laboratory results show a serum creatinine of 1.2 mg/dL and potassium of 4.9 mEq/L. Chest x-ray is unremarkable. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
This patient’s dry nagging cough is most likely a side effect of lisinopril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor.  

The cough usually begins within one to two weeks of instituting therapy, but it can be delayed by up to six months. It is thought to result from increased local concentrations of kinins, the substance P, and prostaglandins. Inhibition of bradykinin and substance P breakdown by ACEI results in their increased concentration, which may induce bronchial irritation and cough via enhanced production of prostaglandins. Moreover, ACE inhibition may also activate the arachidonic pathway, which leads to elevated levels of thromboxane, potentiating bronchoconstriction.    

Treatment includes replacing ACE inhibitors with angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs), which does not affect bradykinin levels and does not cause cough.  

Option Analysis

❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that can increase the excretion of potassium in the urine, leading to hypokalemia (in contrast to hyperkalemia in this patient). Moreover, it does not cause a dry cough.  
❌ Metformin:
Incorrect: Metformin increases insulin sensitivity in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and does not cause cough or hyperkalemia.  
❌ Amiodarone:
Incorrect: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic that can cause pulmonary fibrosis, which may present with cough. This patient’s chest x-ray is normal.  
❌ Digoxin:
Incorrect: Although digoxin may cause hyperkalemia, it is unlikely to cause dry cough as a side effect.  
✅ Lisinopril:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic for new-onset palpitations for the past 3 months. The symptoms occur “out of the blue” for a few seconds at a time. Past medical history is unremarkable. He recalls that his mother had been taking a medication for many years for a chronic condition, but he cannot remember the medication’s name. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 120/83 mmHg, and pulse is 71/min. Cardiac auscultation reveals wide splitting of the second heart sound. An electrocardiogram is significant for tall broad P waves, prolonged PR intervals, and right bundle branch block. A cardiac echocardiogram shows downward displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets. Exposure to which of the following agents in utero most likely contributed to this patient’s cardiac defect?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with arrhythmias, downward displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets, and right bundle branch block. These findings are concerning for Ebstein anomaly, which is caused by in utero exposure to lithium.

Ebstein anomaly is characterized by downward displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets and atrialization of the right ventricle. Ebstein anomalies may present at any point in life.

Severe disease presents with cardiomegaly, hydrops, and tachyarrhythmias. Affected patients often die in utero. The moderate disease can present with cyanosis, congestive heart failure secondary to tricuspid valve regurgitation, and marked cardiomegaly. Patients with moderate disease may present with progressive right-sided heart failure in childhood. Finally, the mild disease often presents with arrhythmias, fatigue, progressive cyanosis, and right-sided heart failure during childhood or adulthood.

Most patients will have an abnormal electrocardiogram with tall and broad P-waves (secondary to right atrial enlargement) and a complete or incomplete right bundle branch block. Symptomatic patients may be managed surgically if they are appropriate candidates. If not, they can be medically managed and treated with a standard heart failure regimen of diuretics and digoxin.  

Option Analysis

❌ Methimazole:
Incorrect: Exposure to methimazole has been associated with aplasia cutis. Patients with this condition have a congenital absence of skin, often presenting as a round area without skin on the scalp. Methimazole treats hyperthyroidism through inhibition of thyroid peroxidase. However, the medication has not been associated with the Ebstein anomaly.  
✅ Lithium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ethanol:
Incorrect: Patients with exposure to alcohol in utero may suffer from fetal alcohol syndrome. This condition classically presents with facial features including a smooth philtrum, thin vermillion, and small palpebral fissures. Another primary feature is central nervous system damage. In contrast, in utero alcohol exposure has not been associated with Ebstein anomaly.  
❌ Thalidomide:
Incorrect: Thalidomide was originally developed as a treatment for morning sickness in pregnant women. It is classically associated with phocomelia, which is the absence and/or underdevelopment of the limbs. However, thalidomide has not been associated with Ebstein anomaly.  
❌ Spironolactone:
Incorrect: Spironolactone is an anti-androgen agent that is used to treat hypertension, heart failure, and hormonal acne. There is a theoretical risk of feminization of a male fetus if exposed in utero, though this concern is not well documented in the literature.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her roommate due to severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The patient took multiple tablets of acetaminophen three hours ago for right foot pain that began several days ago after beginning an intense exercise regimen. The patient has not had any suicidal thoughts, hallucinations, or a history of psychiatric illness. The patient had a runny nose, sinus congestion, and headaches last week. Medications include an oral contraceptive. The patient had one glass of wine last night and normally drinks 2-3 alcoholic drinks per week. The patient does not use tobacco or recreational drugs. Menarche was at age 13, and her last menstrual period was 3 months ago. The patient’s temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 52/min, and blood pressure is 98/68 mmHg. BMI is 15.5 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Physical examination reveals soft, unpigmented hair on the face, arms, and legs. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following factors likely predisposed this patient to her current illness?
questions.solution:
This young adult female is presenting with signs of early acetaminophen toxicity (e.g., abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting). The patient likely has anorexia nervosa given an irregular menstrual cycle, bradycardia, hypotension, reduced BMI, and physical examination findings demonstrating lanugo (e.g., soft, unpigmented hair).

Malnutrition predisposes patients to acetaminophen hepatotoxicity. Hepatocytes mainly metabolize acetaminophen by glucuronidation and sulfation to non-toxic metabolites, which are excreted in urine. A small amount of acetaminophen is metabolized by cytochrome P450 enzymes (also known as microsomal metabolism) to a highly toxic metabolite, N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine, or NAPQI. The hepatic process of glucuronidation relies on hepatic carbohydrate reserves, and in the fasting or malnourished state, glucuronidation of acetaminophen is reduced, which leads to increased microsomal metabolism and subsequent production of NAPQI. Normally, this toxic metabolite is inactivated by an antioxidant called glutathione. In therapeutic doses, acetaminophen does not cause severe side effects. However, depleted glutathione stores, also associated with the fasting and malnourished state, compromise detoxification of NAPQI and predispose to hepatic injury.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/ for international resources. You are not alone.
 



Option Analysis

❌ Age of patient:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen metabolism is age-dependent, with decreased metabolism and increased risk of toxicity occurring with increasing age. This patient is a young adult, making her age an unlikely cause of acetaminophen toxicity.   
✅ Malnutrition:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Recent consumption of alcohol   :
Incorrect: Acute alcohol ingestion is not a significant risk factor for hepatotoxicity; in contrast, it may be protective by competing with acetaminophen for CYP2E1 and, thereby, decreasing the amount of NAPQI produced. Chronic alcohol consumption, in contrast, depletes glutathione stores and synthesis, as well as induces CYP enzymes, resulting in the accumulation of the toxic metabolite NAPQI.   
❌ Recent viral illness   :
Incorrect: Acetaminophen is the first-line therapy for children with fever or pain since aspirin can cause Reye’s syndrome, which is a life-threatening condition that can occur after a viral infection.   
❌ Use of oral contraceptives   :
Incorrect: Medications that induce CYP2E1 enzymes can result in acetaminophen toxicity; since a small amount of acetaminophen is also metabolized by cytochrome P450 enzymes (also known as microsomal metabolism) to a highly toxic metabolite, N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine or NAPQI. CYP inducers can result in elevated NAPQI byproducts. These medications include anticonvulsants, antituberculosis agents, as well as some herbal medications. Oral contraceptive pills are substrates of cytochrome P-450 but are not known to induce these enzymes.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. The patient had undergone a lung transplant 8 months ago and has had several episodes of cytomegalovirus infections since then. Two days ago, the patient was diagnosed with CMV retinitis and was started on an antiviral agent that does not require intracellular activation and is known to bind in-vitro with virally encoded enzymes, such as DNA polymerase and RNA polymerase. Laboratory results are shown below. ECG shows nonspecific ST changes and inverted T waves. Which of the following agents is the most likely cause of this patient’s current presentation?  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium   142 mEq/L 
 Potassium   2.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Calcium  6.5 mg/dL 
 Magnesium  0.9 mEq/L 
 Creatinine  1.0 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient’s generalized tonic-clonic seizure is likely secondary to severe hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia. He is also found to have hypokalemia with ECG changes (nonspecific ST changes and inverted T waves). These electrolyte abnormalities likely resulted from the initiation of forcarnet.  

Foscarnet is an inorganic pyrophosphate analog that inhibits herpesvirus DNA polymerase, RNA polymerase, and HIV reverse transcriptase directly without requiring activation by phosphorylation. Foscarnet blocks the pyrophosphate binding site of these enzymes and inhibits cleavage of pyrophosphate from deoxynucleotide triphosphates, leading to chain termination. It is indicated for the treatment of acyclovir-resistant HSV infections. It is also used as an alternative to ganciclovir for the prophylaxis and treatment of CMV infections in immunocompromised individuals.    

Major adverse effects include nephrotoxicity and electrolyte abnormalities (hypo- or hypercalcemia, hypo- or hyperphosphatemia, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia) that can lead to seizures. The principal mode of viral resistance to the drug involves mutation of the DNA polymerase.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cidofovir:
Incorrect: Although cidofovir is effective against CMV retinitis in immunocompromised patients, it is usually associated with nephrotoxicity, causing elevated creatinine levels. Electrolyte disturbances are not usually seen.
✅ Foscarnet:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acyclovir:
Incorrect: Acyclovir is associated with the development of crystal nephropathy and requires activation by viral kinase.
❌ Didanosine:
Incorrect: Didanosine is an antiretroviral medication that is associated with an increased risk of pancreatitis. Electrolyte disturbances are not usually seen and it is not effective against CMV retinitis.
❌ Valganciclovir:
Incorrect: Valganciclovir is a prodrug of ganciclovir. It is typically associated with the development of bone marrow suppression. Electrolyte disturbances are not usually seen.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department complaining of painful skin lesions. The patient has erythematous erosions over the face, limbs, trunk, and oral cavity. Before developing this rash, he developed fever, chills, and sore throat three days ago. He was diagnosed with a generalized tonic-clonic seizure disorder six months ago and is currently taking lamotrigine. The patient is ill-appearing. His temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 117/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg, and SpO2 of 94%. Skin examination reveals blistering lesions and erosions in the oral cavity, face, upper limb, and trunk. A lateral pressure to the skin results in the shedding of the epidermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). SJS is a life-threatening type IV hypersensitivity reaction mediated by cytotoxic T-cells (CD8+ T-cells). The condition is characterized by necrosis of the epithelium of the skin and mucosal membranes, resulting in blistering lesions and erosions, fever, and systemic illness. Involved areas typically include the skin of the face, trunk, and limbs and mucous membranes.  

Many common medications can trigger SJS. Anticonvulsants associated with SJS include lamotrigine, carbamazepine, phenytoin, and ethosuximide. 


Option Analysis

✅ Stevens-Johnson syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Erythema multiforme :
Incorrect: This patient’s skin lesions, involvement of mucosal membranes, fever, and history of lamotrigine use suggest Stevens-Johnson syndrome. 
❌ Staphylococcal scalded-skin syndrome :
Incorrect: Staphylococcal scalded-skin syndrome is associated with blistering lesions, skin tenderness, and fever; however, mucosal membranes are spared. This condition is more commonly seen in infants and children <4 years of age.
❌ Pemphigus Vulgaris :
Incorrect: Pemphigus Vulgaris can present with blisters, mucosal lesions, and fever, but it is primarily seen in older patients. Also, the association with using lamotrigine makes Stevens-Johnson syndrome the more likely diagnosis. 
❌ Bullous pemphigoid:
Incorrect: Bullous pemphigoid is a blistering disorder characterized by tense bullae that are usually itchy and may turn painful with time. Mucosal lesions can sometimes be seen, but fever is rare.
